No. D.3700-EGI/47 dated the 15th October, 1947, on the subject cited above is forwarded herewith for information and guidance. ENCLOSURE . The accounts #f the late Central Government for the period 1st April 47, zo 14th August 47, are being kept open till the 31st March 48, for the adjustment of all transactions relatable to the pre-partition period and occurring in either Dominion after the partition. But after the 31st December 47, only transactions involving Bb. 1 lakh or over will be adjusted against the combined account. Steps should be taken to see that all transactions relating to the pre-partition period are adjusted as early as possible. 2* It has been agreed with the Pakistan Government that each Dominion should aispose of claims arising after the partition in its area but relating to the pre-partition period up to a limit of Bs. 50,000, lists of decisions being sent by each Dominion to the other in respect of all decisions involving over Hi. 10,000. Claims involving over Ifr.50,000 should be decided only after consultation with the other Dominion. The Dominion in which the claim is received should send to the other Dominion wh a self contained statement of the case so that a decision may be reached without the avoidable transit of the files. If in any case the Dominion consulted asks to see the files or it is considered necessary that the files should be shown there is no objection to this being done. 2* All Ministries should immediately review the sanctions issued before the partition and continuing since then to see if any modifications are necessary. In the case of sanctions relating to the Provinces which remained wholly in the Indian Dominion it may not be necessary to doso. But for sanctions issued in the Provinces which have been divided it may be necessary to reduce the scale of sanctioned expenditure. Ministries should use their discretion in undertaking this review which should be completed in a months time , and the result reported to this Ministry. It will be realised that no review is necessary in respect of sanctions operative in those areas which are now included in Pakistan as this is no longer the concern of the Indian Dominion.i No. —61/2. physicalDescription.extent: The correspondence is arranged in chronological order from the front to the back of the file, except where enclosures of an earlier date are filed after their relevant covering letter, and terminates with a set of notes at folios 55-62. Circled serial numbers in ink (red for incoming, blue/black for outgoing correspondence), which occur throughout the file, refer to entries in the notes.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 64; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-39; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file contains the statement of budget estimates for the Political Agency, Bahrain for the financial year 1947-48 and associated financial statements and correspondence for the same period.The correspondence is mainly between staff of the Political Agency, Bahrain, and the Political Residency in the Persian Gulf. There is also some correspondence from the Government of India.The budget estimates cover the following areas of expenditure: pay of officers; pay of establishment; allowances, honoraria etc.; secret expenditure; other charges; and Dubai Hospital. Also included are detailed pay statements for officers and establishment; statement of special war expenditure; and statements of anticipated excesses and savings.The correspondence includes covering letters; papers concerning a request for estimates of budget excesses under the heads of office allowance, central contract grant, and launch grant (folios 14-27); notification of closure of the Government of India's accounts (folio 47); and requests for confirmation of budget figures.The date range gives the covering dates of the main items of correspondence. The earliest document in the file is a letter on folio 45r, dated 26 August 1938, which forms a reused folio for the copy letter on folio 45v. However, it is the letter on folio 45v (which is upside down) that is the actual filed correspondence item, dated by a Political Agency, Bahrain receipt stamp of 26 November 1947. The last dated item in the file is a Political Agency, Bahrain receipt stamp on the last item of correspondence, showing that it was received on 29 December 1948.
